task.Question: If Eliud Kipchoge could maintain his record-making marathon pace indefinitely, how many thousand hours would it take him to run the distance between the Earth and the Moon its closest approach? Please use the minimum perigee value on the Wikipedia page for the Moon when carrying out your calculation. Round your result to the nearest 1000 hours and do not use any comma separators if necessary.

Annotator Metadata.Steps:
1. Googled Eliud Kipchoge marathon pace to find 4min 37sec/mile
2. Converted into fractions of hours.
3. Found moon periapsis in miles (225,623 miles).
4. Multiplied the two to find the number of hours and rounded to the nearest 100 hours.
Annotator Metadata.Tools:
1. A web browser.
2. A search engine.
3. A calculator.

steps.content: If Eliud Kipchoge could maintain his record-making marathon pace indefinitely, how many thousand hours would it take him to run the distance between the Earth and the Moon its closest approach? Please use the minimum perigee value on the Wikipedia page for the Moon when carrying out your calculation. Round your result to the nearest 1000 hours and do not use any comma separators if necessary.

plan: Look up the minimum perigee distance between the Earth and the Moon on the Wikipedia page for the Moon.
Find Eliud Kipchoge's marathon record pace in minutes per kilometer.
Convert Kipchoge's pace to hours per kilometer.
Calculate the total time in hours it would take to run the distance from the Earth to the Moon using the formula: total time = (distance in kilometers) * (hours per kilometer).
Convert the total time from hours to thousand hours by dividing by 1000.
Round the result to the nearest 1000 hours.

given_facts: Eliud Kipchoge's marathon pace is record-making.
The distance between the Earth and the Moon at its closest approach is referred to as perigee.
facts_to_lookup: Minimum perigee distance between the Earth and the Moon
Eliud Kipchoge's marathon record pace in minutes per kilometer
facts_to_derive: Total time in hours to run the distance from the Earth to the Moon using Kipchoge's pace

serp.title: Orbit of the Moon
serp.content: On average, the distance to the Moon is about 385,000 km (239,000 mi) from Earth's centre, which corresponds to about 60 Earth radii or 1.282 light-seconds.

serp.title: Lunar distance
serp.content: This shows that the smallest perigee occurs at either new moon or full moon (ca 356870 km), as does the greatest apogee (ca 406079 km), whereas the greatest ...

serp.title: Moon
serp.content: The Moon is Earth's only natural satellite. It orbits at an average distance of 384,400 km (238,900 mi), about 30 times the diameter of Earth.

serp.title: Supermoon
serp.content: A supermoon is a full moon or a new moon that nearly coincides with perigee—the closest that the Moon comes to the Earth in its elliptic orbit ...

serp.title: Moon illusion
serp.content: Across different full moons, the Moon's angular diameter can vary from 29.43 arcminutes at apogee to 33.5 arcminutes at perigee—a variation of around 14% in ...

steps.quote_with_fact: the smallest perigee occurs at either new moon or full moon (ca 356870 km)

serp.content: On 12 October 2019, Kipchoge ran the marathon distance for the Ineos 1:59 Challenge in Vienna, achieving a time of 1:59:40.2, becoming the first person in ...

serp.title: Ineos 1:59 Challenge
serp.content: The Ineos 1:59 Challenge, held on 12 October 2019, was an attempt by Kenyan athlete Eliud Kipchoge to break the two-hour mark for running the marathon distance.

serp.title: The incredible science behind Eliud Kipchoge's 1:59 ...

serp.title: Eliud Kipchoge Breaks Two-Hour Marathon Barrier
serp.content: 14 Oct 2019 — Eliud Kipchoge of Kenya ran 26.2 miles in a once-inconceivable time of 1 hour 59 minutes 40 seconds. In becoming the first person to cover the marathon ...

steps.fact_description: Eliud Kipchoge's marathon pace in minutes per kilometer
steps.quote_with_fact: Kipchoge ran the marathon distance for the Ineos 1:59 Challenge in Vienna, achieving a time of 1:59:40.2

reasoning: Eliud Kipchoge's marathon time is 1 hour 59 minutes and 40.2 seconds.
Convert this time into total minutes: 1 hour = 60 minutes, so total time = 60 + 59 + (40.2 / 60) = 119.67 minutes.
Calculate Kipchoge's pace in minutes per kilometer: pace = total time / distance = 119.67 minutes / 42.195 km.
Convert the pace from minutes per kilometer to hours per kilometer by dividing the pace by 60.
The minimum perigee distance to the Moon is 356870 kilometers.
Calculate the total time in hours to run this distance using Kipchoge's pace: total time = distance * hours per kilometer.
Convert the total time from hours to thousand hours by dividing by 1000.
Round the result to the nearest 1000 hours.

steps.code:
marathon_time_minutes = 119.67
marathon_distance_km = 42.195
pace_hours_per_km = marathon_time_minutes / 60 / marathon_distance_km
moon_distance_km = 356870
total_time_hours = moon_distance_km * pace_hours_per_km
total_time_thousand_hours = total_time_hours / 1000
rounded_time = round(total_time_thousand_hours / 1000) * 1000
rounded_time

steps.overview: Calculated the time it would take Eliud Kipchoge to run the distance from the Earth to the Moon at perigee.
